caption:
Looking for your next adventure? National Geographic’s picks for Best of the World 2026 are here. 🌎 

Developed by our team of travel experts and global editors, our #BestOfTheWorld guide contains the most awe-inspiring, meaningful, and immersive experiences for the year ahead. 

Our bags are packed—see where we’re headed at the link in our bio or at natgeo.com/bestoftheworld

Photograph by @chrisburkard, Verb Photo

As French general and ruler Napoleon Bonaparte returned from a disastrous attempt to conquer Russia in 1812, his army lost tens of thousands of men with many believed to have died from "trench fever" and typhus. 

But when researchers recently analyzed ancient DNA from 13 teeth collected from a mass grave in Lithuania, they were surprised when they did not find evidence of either scourge. So what really happened? 

Head to the link in bio to explore how centuries-old DNA reveals truths about Napoleon’s “big mistake.”

Painting by Adolph Northen (1828-1876), Barbieri et al., Current Biology

Wildfires are becoming more brutal, causing unprecedented destruction and burning even hotter. When Nat Geo Explorer and photographer @mattblack_blackmatt saw the effects of these catastrophic fires so close to his home in the Sierra Nevada, he turned an industrial thermal camera on the aftermath and burned landscapes. His haunting images expose the beauty and devastation left in their wake.

Learn more about his work at the link in bio.

Soar above the Georgian Old Town of Hull, England. Discover new green spaces and public art inspired by the city’s 800 years of maritime history, as well as its plethora of museums and newly revitalized waterfront area that's breathing new life into one of northern England's best-kept secrets.

Out now: Nat Geo's #BestOfTheWorld 2026 list features the most exciting, authentic, and immersive destinations in travel right now. See the full list at the link in bio. 

Video by Sam Walker (@samwalker.uk).

If you’re sending a robot to another world to search for signs of microscopic alien life, you need an extremely clean environment. One wouldn’t want to mistake a stowaway for the first evidence of extraterrestrials or expose humans to potentially dangerous microbes on long-term trips to space.
 
That’s why spacecraft are often built in clean rooms, some of the most sterile environments on Earth. But in 2013, scientists were shocked to discover a brand-new type of bacteria had invaded not just one spacecraft clean room, but two—thousands of miles apart. Now, a recent study finally uncovers the secret to its survival.
 
Learn more about this bacterium and how it escaped detection at the link in bio.
 
Micrograph courtesy of NASA/JPL-Caltech

Photos by @babaktafreshi | Shown here is Comet Lemmon (C/2025 A6) a few nights ago in Maine. Slides 1-3 are close-up views through a telephoto lens, while 4 shows how small the comet appears in a wide-angle lens or to the unaided eye in a dark sky. Currently at its peak of brightness, the comet looks best through a small telescope or a pair of binoculars, west-northwest after dusk.
Beneath the streets of Paris, the bones of nearly six million people are arranged in the city's catacombs—stretching for almost a mile. Learn more about Paris' macabre underworld at the link in bio.

On October 15, 2025, @jimwmorrison completed the first ski descent of Mount Everest’s Hornbein Couloir—solving what elite ski mountaineers worldwide called "the last great problem."

Skiing down this 9,000-foot vertical line from Everest's summit at 29,032 feet, combined with the successful summit ascent, represents the most significant achievement in ski mountaineering history. The feat required five years of logistical planning, three expedition attempts, and a lifetime of preparation.

Academy Award-winning ‘Free Solo’ directors @chaivasarhelyi and @jimmychin captured Morrison’s grueling physical and emotional journey for the upcoming @natgeodocs film “Everest North” (working title).

Photo by @joelsartore | Named for their wiggly snouts, rufous elephant shrews are part of Afrotheria, an evolutionary clade of African animals. They are not true shrews, and though they aren’t much larger than a mouse, they are actually more closely related to elephants! Photo taken @aquazooduesseldorf. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Once believed to be a safe haven for marine life, the Red Sea faced a harsh reality check during an intense heatwave in 2023. A new paper states that this thermal event bleached sea anemones and nearly wiped out their famous residents, destroying over 94 percent of the area’s clownfish population. While these resilient species were once thought to thrive in this area, experts believe this may have been a tipping point that could spell trouble for reefs around the world.

Discover what this means for the future of our oceans at the link in bio.

Photographs by @morganbennettsmith

Hiking is a way of life in South Korea, where treks through national parks fill many people’s weekends. The new Dongseo Trail, expected to be completed in 2027, builds on that momentum. Stretching 527 miles from coast-to-coast, it takes inspiration from Spain's Camino de Santiago and connects communities across the country. 

Discover more about where to find your next big adventure in our Best of the World 2026 list at the link in bio. 

Video by @junmichaelpark

Generation after generation of bearded vultures all used the same nesting site in a cave in southern Spain. When researchers rappelled down the sides of a cliff to reach the site, they found that the cave's cool, dry air preserved the vultures' nesting materials so well that human-made objects, including 13th-century shoes added to the nests hundreds of years ago, were still recognizable.

Learn more about the objects and how vultures and other bird species create archeological and biological treasure troves at the link in bio.

Photograph by Sergio Couto

In Namibia’s desert, a matriarch leads her family through a landscape of extremes. Her knowledge—passed down through generations—guides the herd to hidden water sources and fleeting shade. For her calf, each moment is a lesson in strength and survival, and a reminder that even in the driest places, life finds a way.

Video by Martin Gregus Jr. @mywildlive

Once viewed as a hormone only for men, testosterone for women has quietly become one of the most talked-about topics in women’s health. The hormone plays a vital role in women’s mood, libido, and bone health. As more women look for ways to manage menopause symptoms, testosterone is being touted as a modern fix for everything from energy to anti-aging, but researchers warn that many claims still outpace the evidence.
 
Find out what experts say about when it actually does help—and when it doesn’t—at the link in bio.

Photograph by naumoid, Getty Images

Photo by Jason Gulley @jason_gulley_science | Manatees and jack crevalles swim in the spring-fed Homosassa River on Florida's central Gulf Coast on a cold January morning. Manatees and several species of primarily saltwater fish migrate into Florida's freshwater springs and spring-fed rivers to keep warm during winter. While temperatures in the Gulf can plunge into the 50s during winter, groundwater discharging from the limestone aquifer feeding Homosassa Springs is a constant 74 to 75 degrees Fahrenheit (about 23.5 degrees Celsius).

A local resident stumbled upon the remains of the world’s longest woolly rhino horn—dating back 19,700 years—in the thawing permafrost of Yakutia, Siberia.

Measuring about 5 feet 5 inches (165 cm) long, scientists say its sheer size, growth rings, and shape may reveal new clues about Ice Age life, including how long these ancient beasts lived and which sex dominated the tundra. As ice continues to melt, exposing more of the frozen ground, discoveries like this are rewriting what we know about Earth’s ancient giants.

Find out more at the link in bio.

Photographs by Ruslan Belyaev and Mammoth Museum, Yakutsk, Russia

Discussing the new season of his documentary series, Limitless: Live Better Now, Chris Hemsworth talks about how his life has changed since the first season, what drew him to return, and the incredible challenges he experienced in the second season.

#LimitlessWithChrisHemsworth is now streaming on @DisneyPlus, available on @Hulu until November 8.

Tasiujarjuaq & Weeneebeg: Bays of Life is a new feature-length documentary from @natgeopristineseas spotlighting Cree and Inuit efforts to protect the pristine waters of Hudson and James Bay. Blending intimate storytelling, stunning underwater footage, and animations of local legends, the film celebrates millennia of connection to the bays—and aims to inspire Indigenous-led protection for generations to come. 

Streaming now on Nat Geo's Youtube. Read more about this story at the link in bio. Photos by @manusanfelix.

Take a journey along a farther-flung Silk Road city, Khiva, Uzbekistan, that outshines its more famous neighbors. 

Posed on the edge of the vast desert, explore Itchan Kala fortress, a UNESCO World Heritage site, where geometric-patterned tiled monuments and opulent palaces have all been meticulously restored. Or head to the new Silk Road-themed Arda Khiva resort with its water park and amphitheater. 

Discover the beauty of Khiva, Uzbekistan and see our full #BestOfTheWorld 2026 picks at the link in bio. 

Video by @_aliona_kardash

Photos by @dina_litovsky | The Cat Fanciers' Association International Cat Show & Expo, held in Cleveland, Ohio, is the largest gathering of cats and cat enthusiasts in the world. The show is part contest, part social gathering, a place where obsession and affection blur, and the pursuit of the perfect cat becomes its own art form.

Learn more about what it takes to be a champion feline at the link in bio.
